title: Sheffield United  devastated  by death of longest - serving player Maddy Cusack aged 27
body_text:
Sheffield United ‘devastated’ by death of longest-serving player Maddy Cusack aged 27
Maddy Cusack was a popular player at Sheffield United thanks to her professionalism and personality and will be 'sadly missed' by staff at Bramall Lane, the club said
Sheffield United players and staff have been left ‘heartbroken’ by the death of women’s team midfielder Maddy Cusack at the age of 27.
Maddy, named vice-captain last month, had just started her sixth season with the Blades in the Women’s Championship and was the longest-serving player in their current squad. She joined Sheffield United, who play at Bramall Lane, halfway through their first campaign in the women’s second tier in January 2019 and last season became the first woman to reach 100 appearances for the club.
The former England youth international signed a new contract extension with the Blades in July. She also worked as a marketing executive at the football club.
United’s chief executive officer Stephen Bettis said: “This is heart-breaking news for everyone at Bramall Lane. Maddy had a unique position of being part of a number of teams at Sheffield United and was popular with everyone that she came into contact with.
“Her personality and professionalism made her a credit to her family – she will be sadly missed. While taking in the news and moving forward, the club will offer as much support as possible to Maddy’s family, friends and colleagues.”
The Blades said talks over “suitable tributes and celebrating Maddy’s life” will continue privately, adding: “The club and Maddy’s family would appreciate a period of privacy and will not comment further at this sad time.”
A statement on the club’s official website read: “Sheffield United Football Club is devastated to report the sad news of the passing of Maddy Cusack.
“Maddy, a women’s team player since 2019 and marketing executive for the Football Club, passed away on Wednesday.
“A respected player, Maddy, 27, last season reached the milestone of 100 appearances for Sheffield United Women.
“Additionally, she was a valued colleague in the offices at Bramall Lane, moving over from the Sheffield United Community Foundation to the club in 2021 to help market all areas of the Blades.”
Baroness Sue Campbell, FA director of women’s football, said everyone was “devastated” to learn about Maddy’s death. She added: “On behalf of the FA, the Lionesses, the Women’s Super League and the Women’s Championship, our thoughts and deepest condolences are with Maddy’s family, friends, team-mates and everyone at Sheffield United.
"Maddy also represented England at age-group level and we will pay tribute to her at an appropriate point. We are in contact with the club and will continue to offer them our full support during this incredibly sad time."
Maddy's old club, Birmingham City, said they were “saddened” to learn of the passing of their former player. “All of our thoughts are with Maddy’s family and friends at this extremely difficult time," they added.
Meanwhile, Arsenal and England defender Leah Williamson tweeted: "Sending all my love and condolences to Maddy’s family at this awful time!"
